conclusion: To solve the problem, I will analyze the velocity-time graphs of objects A and B to determine when they are farthest apart. I will identify the time at which the distance between them is maximized by comparing their positions.

The image shows two velocity-time graphs, labeled A and B. Object A has a constant velocity line, while object B's graph shows a decrease in velocity from a higher initial value, reaching zero at a certain time. Both objects start from the same position at time \( t_1 \) and end at time \( t_2 \).

premise: The distance between two objects moving along a straight line is determined by their positions at any given time.
conclusion: For object A, the velocity is constant, so its position increases linearly with time.

premise: For object B, the velocity decreases over time, causing its position to increase at a decreasing rate.
conclusion: The maximum distance between the two objects occurs when object B has stopped moving (velocity = 0) and object A continues to move.

premise: Object B stops at time \( t_2 \), while object A continues to move at constant velocity.
conclusion: Therefore, the maximum distance between the two objects occurs at time \( t_2 \).
